bread

First of all, we need to mix the flour

over the
yeast. Stir it with a spoon until it all comes together.

a little flour on your hands. So then we knead. Knead for about 10 minutes.
Just pull it back and then push it away.
You want to stretch the gluten, and

and you really want to make it elastic to
build up that kind of

rubber band-like kinda texture and the
reason you want it to be like that
is as the yeast produces air
gas, you don't want it just to sort of escape,
you want that sort-of, that sort-of bendiness of the bread,

the kind of structure of the bread to
really hold the air in.
So it's light and spongy and gorgeous.
We want to create some humidity. Just put the bowl over

Thyme. Just put a little oil on the outside. If you put herbs on dry

onto the the lovely dough, and it will be

comments.text:
I love focaccia so much, and I'm definitely going to try this recipe out!
Gennaro's love for food reminds me so much of my old bosses, a first 
generation Sicilian family. If some of the extended family would visit, 
they'd have them over for a meal in the dining area of the restaurant, cook 
everything in the kitchen while the rest of the staff was working, and the 
smells, sights and tastes they had going on made me fall in love with food 
all over again. :)﻿

+Saeed Mohammed You can freeze it hun for I think 3 months :) Warms well in

comments.author: marie Savino

comments.text:
+Saeed Mohammed If you want to keep a focaccia for more than a day or two, 
once i'ts completely cool cut it in portions and store it in the freezer. 
When you are ready for a slice, take it out and warm it up in the microwave 
(just a few moments) or in the regular warm oven for 10 minutes.
comments.author: Alice Twain

italy. It's covered in plastic wrap and we leave it in the fridge until we 
want to devour it. It lasts ages!
comments.author: simplyshama

comments.text:
+Saeed Mohammed Focaccia is good for the first day (beautiful, fragrant and 
crisp) 
the second day can be heated (but the taste will not be the same)
the third you can trash it! (but it usually disappears the first day ;-))
source: An Italian consumer of Focaccia
comments.author: Massimo Cerra

just make some home made breadcrumbs.
